In this section, we’ll ask about:

  • how much funding you are bidding for
  • the number of households that you (and your consortium, if applicable) intend to support by the end of March 2031
  • your funding spreadsheet for 125 households
  • your second funding spreadsheet (if applicable)
  • whether you have secured additional funding outside of this grant
  • the source of these funds and how you will ensure activities are not double-funded (if applicable)
  • how you would scale up or scale down your project
  • whether your Sponsor Groups will fundraise
  • details on how your Sponsor Groups will fundraise and how you will keep this funding separate from this grant’s funding

pages.title: Upload your funding spreadsheet for 125 households

components.name: MrmSgl
components.content:
Provide the total cost of your project based on 125 households with a breakdown of the costs by year and activity. Ensure that they add up to the amount you are bidding for or provide an explanation. This should not exceed a total of £1,036,250 for the 125 households. This will be used as a benchmark for assessment.

Your funding spreadsheet should include:

  • Gross salaries
  • Staff expenses
  • Project costs (for example, IT)
  • Sponsor related costs (for example, DBS checks)
  • Any professional fees
  • Central costs
  • Any additional funding
If you would like a funding spreadsheet template, email sponsorship@communities.gov.uk

MHCLG reserves the right to award varied funding per household, for example if one Principal Sponsor is going to carry out more of the Principal Sponsor activities across the entire scheme.

How value for money will be scored

For all bids that score a total of over 50% in the initial assessment, we will then score the value for money of full bids (including bids for higher number of families). At that point, the applicant achieving the lowest cost per household across either 125 households or any number of households greater than 125 will achieve the 7%.

The 7% funding weighting section within the ‘Value for money’ section will be scored in order of the lowest cost per household receiving the highest score (7%), with the next lowest cost receiving the next highest score (6%), reducing by one each time to 0%, as follows:

  • Lowest cost = 7%
  • Second lowest cost = 6%
  • Third lowest cost = 5%
  • Fourth lowest cost = 4%
  • Fifth lowest cost = 3%
  • Sixth lowest cost = 2%
  • Seventh lowest cost = 1%
  • Eighth lowest cost = 0%

In the first instance we will assess value for money against proposals for 125 households as a benchmark to compare to other applicants.
